summary: This document is a Touhy request letter from the law firm Kaplan Hecker & Fink LLP to U.S. Attorney Geoffrey S. Berman, dated February 25, 2020, on behalf of a plaintiff known as Jane Doe. The letter demands records from the DOJ related to the criminal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein to support Doe's civil lawsuit against his estate. The document includes the complaint from the civil case (Doe v. Indyke et al.), which details allegations that Epstein repeatedly sexually abused Jane Doe from around 2002 to 2005, starting when she was 14 years old. This is a civil complaint filed by Jane Doe against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein, alleging sexual assault, battery, and intentional infliction of emotional distress. It details a pattern of abuse over three years, the facilitation by Epstein's employees, and the impact on the victim's life. It also references Epstein's 2019 indictment, death, and will.

keyFacts: Jane Doe alleges Jeffrey Epstein sexually abused her repeatedly from around 2002 to 2005, starting when she was 14 years old, at his mansion at 9 East 71st Street in New York.

The document reveals that around 2008, Epstein retained attorneys Brendan White and Diarmuid White to represent Jane Doe during the FBI's investigation, allegedly to prevent law enforcement from speaking with her.
Jane Doe is believed to be "Minor Victim-1" referenced in the 2019 federal indictment against Jeffrey Epstein for sex trafficking.

The Touhy request seeks a wide range of evidence from the DOJ, including interview records, evidence of cash payments, communications about the attorneys Epstein retained for Doe, and any images/videos of Doe recovered from Epstein's home.

The complaint details a pattern of escalating sexual abuse by Epstein, including masturbation, forced touching, use of a vibrator, digital penetration, and encounters with other victims and an adult woman.

The plaintiff, Jane Doe, alleges she was sexually assaulted by Jeffrey Epstein 'countless times' over a three-year period when she was a minor, following a common pattern of targeting vulnerable girls and escalating abuse.

Epstein's employees Sarah Kellen and Lesley Groff are specifically named as facilitators who scheduled the plaintiff's visits, requested she bring other girls, and handled payments, and were listed as potential co-conspirators in Epstein's 2008 Non-Prosecution Agreement.
The complaint details severe and lasting harm to the plaintiff, including PTSD, depression, anxiety, and profound impacts on her family life, education, and ability to work.
The document states Epstein paid hundreds of thousands of dollars to potential co-conspirators in November 2018, after media reports about his 2008 plea deal, suggesting an attempt to buy silence.
Epstein's will, executed two days before his death, directs his estate to a trust called 'The 1953 Trust', with Darren Indyke and Richard Kahn named as executors and trustees.
